This is a part of the book written by Rudin. I was formalizing the proof of theorem 2.33.
In the proof, suppose K is compact relative to X, and let { V_a} be a collection of sets, open relative to Y. My question is, if K is compact relative to X, how can I pick a cover open relative to Y?

Are you using Mathlib's definition of compactness, or your own definition based on Rudin? In Mathlib we have docs#CompactSpace for stating that a space is compact (independently of anything), and docs#IsCompact for compact subsets of a topological space. But none of them really allow to state theorem 2.33 as is, because K cannot have both type Set X and Set Y.
So really my question is: what are you ultimately trying to do?

I am formalising the theorem 2.33, I misunderstood what he was trying to do in the proof by picking a collection of set open relative to Y. I didn't write one statement in my own definition of {V_a}, so there was something I can't prove in my lean code. I think I know how it is now.
Generally, ther problem is that I didn't intro a feature

About the Set X and Set Y issue ,I managed to
deal with it using injective maps.
Ruize Chen has marked this topic as resolved.
